p:
Three of twelve panelists participating in Round 3, however, strongly disagreed with the above rationales and considered the “benefits [of sharing anonymized genomic data] outweigh the harms” (P3ew99). Furthermore, these panelists reasoned that the risks of sharing even anonymized genomic data via open access depended on the number of reported cases or variants available in a database where the data were shared and its provenance i.e. how the data was sourced:
If you have tons of children and just a list of variants, and maybe one additional source of data, then yes you may have more likelihood of knowing who that patient is. But this does not matter in the long-term if you ask patients and their families especially in the rare disease context—PSbg4.
